text: the International Herald Tribune in the
New York Times this is Suzy Menkes
talking to Chris Van Noten about the iht
luxury conference in New Delhi dries van
noten working out of Belgium you've had
a love affair with India and its crafts
and it skills for over 20 years how did
it all begin I was introduced to India
by a very good friends of mine and she
took me there on a trip and I was really
at such incredible country with such
tradition of color and and use of color
and embroideries and beauty just beauty
in general so that for me it was really
overwhelming so I really wanted to work
together with those people when you talk
about working with India you have taken
the skills of India and the colors but
you've made them into something that is
your own and is also European in style
my collaboration with India's is so nice
because they teach me and I teach them
so it's a very good collaboration it's
not that i dictate what i have to do
they have also always kind of a certain
input and just the skill is so fantastic
so that it just pushes me to create
every time other things and to go
further every time when we talk about
india we're talking about a subcontinent
with enormously different areas
different colors different workmanship
is this something that you have worked
with or have you taken a specific region
our employees are done in Calcutta but
sometimes people forget that in India
every region has its own skills and
because i really adore to use the skills
so sometimes also i just say ok try
travel around in india bring me things
which go first look quite interesting
sometimes quite contrasting also often a
piece of fabric is woven in the south of
India rule
coming with more from the north of India
embroideries are burning from Delhi to
Calcutta to Mumbai so it's really some
pieces of travelling around India
completely just be woven there
applicated in another region and then
employ it in another place tell us about
India and high-tech we know of course
about the service centers for telephones
but I don't think most people think of
high-tech in relation to Indian fabrics
it's going very fast there so it's new
for this also so it's not that I going
to locate my whole production to India
but it gives me much more possibilities
and that of course for fashion designer
is always fantastic because we need
every time new challenges little by
little also there we have now printers
were working with digital print which
gives us a lot of possibilities so
that's really high technology new
technology introduced in India now if
you had three pieces of advice to give
to a young indian designer who wants to
make it internationally using his or her
own country skills what would those
three things be look to the past but
respect the skills but don't be
nostalgic and I think it's specially
don't don't try to do they make what was
done in the past I think it's really
necessary to look to the future and just
always go one step further trace van
outen working beautifully with India
thank you for talking to the
International Herald Tribune thank you
